The conversation on whether or not kids are better learners than adults misses key set of skills that adults have developed, that young children are still developing. Young children are definitely better at acquiring basic raw information that helps them form an understanding of the world that they're interacting with, but we spend most of our time as children learning much more complicated skills for what to do with that information.

The topic of acquiring languages is one where there's a lot of heated debate. There's a myth that adults are not as good at learning languages as children. Well it's true that an adult who has never learned a language would have a much harder time learning one than a child, adults have a language that they've learned before as a basis for acquiring new languages. We can use mnemonics, we understand contexts better, we can structure our study, and we can read.

Well I think it's fair to argue that learning to read for the first time is a place where a child definitely has an advantage, having skills like reading as an adult gives adults significantly better access to tools for learning things like languages or complex ideas that are simply inaccessible to children who are still developing the fundamental skills necessary for advanced learning.

Sure, the brain of a child has a superpower, but the brain of an adult has spent years, even decades, developing complex skills that I believe significantly close the gap in learning ability. In other words, our metacognitive abilities, or our ability to understand how we learn and think, confers major advantages over children who lack this level of metacognitive capability.

One of my cousins is married to a fellow who was "born blind" due to horribly, congenitally scarred lenses; he had ONLY sensations of light & dark with NOTHING MORE. He attended a school for the blind, read in Braille, used a white cane, graduated from HS and College, "the whole nine yards," ALL AS A BLIND PERSON. As an middle-aged adult he heard about implantable intraocular lenses, and asked about those, only to be told "By YOUR AGE your brain is COMPLETELY convinced that you're blind - LENS IMPLANTS WILL NEVER WORK."
Thankfully, ONE of his doctors was able to (somehow), test "around" his badly scarred lenses and discover that his retinas WERE STILL RESPONSIVE TO IMAGES! SO, he had bilateral IOL implant surgeries IN HIS FORTIES (believe this or not, but IT'S TRUE!), and shocked ALMOST EVERYONE -- HE NOW HAS 20/20 VISION IN EACH EYE! I've met him, and it's phenomenally WONDERFUL! I would NEVER have believed it if I hadn't seen it!
Actually, I've seen OTHER "medical miracles" that Physicians said simply "couldn't happen" (even supervised one all by myself, averting several body part amputations!), so I ALWAYS try to remind folks that:
EVERY
BODY
IS

I'm a nurse in a specialized, in hospital, rehabilitation facility that treats people with severe neurological disabilities including everything ranging from paralysis to complete coma. Especially in strokes and brain hemorrhages the neural plasticity of the brain is one of the key concepts that allows regaining function and/or sensitivity in the affected areas. There are even methods were people with hemiparesis (loss of function/sensitivity in one half of the body, contra-lateral to the damaged area) get a mirror placed on their median body line, get the eye on the "bad" side patched, and have to perform functions and experience sensitivity on the "good" side. This can somewhat trick the brain into thinking its actually the "bad" side doing these things and thus restoring and/or strengthening neural connection to that side.

Also, there seems to be a confusion of two things here:
(1) The variability of neuroplasticity, and
(2) Repair following gross insult such as a stroke or TBI.
(1) is associated largely with GABA and other change moderators while (2) is controlled by proteins such as "nogo" which prohibit massive regrowth of axons and dendrites by cells which have otherwise survived. Again, two very different mechanisms.

The most recent studies suggest that neurogenesis doesn't occur after gestation ends (when previous studies suggested that the dentate gyrus could perform neurogenesis into adulthood). New synapses may/will form and be pruned away well into adulthood, but to say new neurons, the actual neuronal cell, will form is an a somewhat harmful over generalization. When neurons die, they do not come back because in adulthood new neurons can not form; however, that doesn't mean that the brain can't adapt to their loss through a "rewiring" or plasticity of the surround synapses. This processes is involved mainly with the glutamatergic system under the context of learning and memory, but in reference to critical periods, I think this would be better explained by acknowledging the role of NGF and BDNF as they play a crucial role in the routing of neuronal circuitry as well the survival of the neuron itself. There is new research suggesting that using growth factors, they may be able to reopen critical period (in humans idk bc there has not be human trials). There are multiple theories on why a growth period ends that range from myelination, a change in glutamatergic receptors, as well as constraint of cortical activation. The reason GABA makes " circuit breakers " in the brain wiring is to prevent overstimulation of the Neurons in the brain from strong sensory input.   Around 6 years of age the brains development is stalled while excessive Neurons are destroyed, failure to remove excess Neurons is one of the prime suspects in late Diagnosis Autism (anti-vax crowds usually associate this with vaccinations that happen around the same age, there is no actual connection other than overlap in age for receiving vaccinations and the normal period of this brain developments).  The next stages are reinforcing and adding Neurons to the most active pathways and the addition of blocks " circuit breakers " that reduce or prevent signals from progressing down the incorrect pathways.  So any drug that reduces the effectiveness of GABA is going to have seizers as a side effect.  (If seizers is spelled wrong blame autocorrect :-))
